To the back right side there is a world war 2 memorial as well for the unknown solider and it has names of lots of other country's soldiers who passed during the war. There is also containers of sand from the different countries involved in the war. A nice place to see.

Review: Entrance fee is 300 yen per person. Comes with a guide book and insence stick to place in the middle of the grounds. There are other sites in the forest behind the giant statue to check out, as well. We were warned of wild monkeys being on the grounds and to be wary of them. Come with bug spray if you plan to spend more than 10 mins here. Mosquitos are everywhere due to the still water in front of the statue.

Author: Raja Reddy
Review: This place is amazing. Lot of good energy here. Make sure to see the statues inside the back of the giant Buddha. Hardly any visitors (we came twice in our one week in Kyoto), which was great for us to really be able to enjoy the peace here, but bad for the memorial as it needs funding. Parts of the buildings are rundown, which likely could be solved if this place was busier.  Even though you can see part of the giant Buddha from outside, the view from inside is way better, so go here!

Author: Jeanine BB
Review: In the area of a number of temples this exists as a memorial to soldiers that died in WWII. It is large, and impressive. We enjoyed this visit. They gave us some incense sticks to light and place in the shrine. Beautifully cared for spot. The Buddha's footprints are hard to photograph as you can't get very high above them, but they are quite beautiful carvings. Very well done. Enjoyed our visit.

Author: Lizzie Smith
Review:
I stumbled upon this on a day of wandering, it took my breath away and I was moved to tears. In addition to the gigantic statue there are other, really meaningful shrines. On paying to enter you‚Äôre given a stick of incense and told it‚Äôs in remembrance of the unknown soldiers of WWII that gave their lives. I usually associate these thoughts with the Allies.  My Dad, who was in the army aged 17-65 died a few years ago. I was overcome and couldn‚Äôt stop weeping. I found a place of quiet contemplation, a shrine to unborn babies - cue more weeping. Then the memorial hall for the unknown soldier. It‚Äôs an active Buddhist monastery, and felt special and unique in the somewhat gauzy Disney culture of Kyoto. Come.
There are also two very very cool cars on display.

Review: Great admission fee which includes an incredible stick, and very quiet and peaceful. Preferred this to some of the other, more crowded sacred spots as it didn't feel so 'touristy' and there was a lot more to see than you think looking from the outside.

Review: You can find it in Higashiyama area, near Kiyomizu-dera! The statue was amazingly huge and I was impressed by it! The best season to come here is when the Sakura blooms, and the weather in spring is also more comfortable!

Author: gradhito
Review: One of the largest Buddha statue in Japan perhaps, It was really captivating indeed. Was a shame that I (and many people) didn't take the time to pay a visit inside.

Author: Taiyo
Review:
I have family who fought for the #UnitedStates and fought for #Japan during World War II.

I paid respect to the Buddhist monument in Kyoto, Ryozen, a dedication for the unknown dead Japanese soldiers of World War II.

I witnessed a ceremony, one of the participant's eyes met mine and a palpable unknown recognition quickly arose between us for a few seconds, as if she unexplainably knew exactly who I and my family were.

When leaving, a buddhist monk scurringly passed by me, his eyes briefly meeting my eyes, before quickly glancing down while leaning his body and pulling his clothing away from me as in fear of a plague, when passing me.

I have no clue why.

I don't think I will forget that moment ever.

Author: Selea Kerr
Review: Such a beautiful an amazing place!

Author: ‰ªäÂüéÊ≠£‰∫∫
Review: Close to Nene no Michi. A statue of Kannon in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, erected in 1955 by Hirosuke Ishikawa, the founder of the Teisan Group, to commemorate the war dead and victims of World War II. It is 24m high, weighs about 500t, and is made of steel concrete. It is operated by the religious corporation Ryozen Kannon Church. Below the statue of Kannon, there is a sanctuary where the principal image of the Kannon, the Eleven-Faced Kannon, is enshrined. In the memorial hall, there is a monument to the world's unknown soldier, and four memorial services are held each day. Betsuin includes Tokyo Betsuin Tokujiji and Akasaka Betsuin.

Review: A statue of Kannon (Ryozen Kannon) with a height of 24m and a total weight of about 500t is enshrined above the main hall. The principal image of the twelve zodiac guardians is enshrined as a Buddha in the womb, and the principal image of worship is the eleven-faced eight-armed Kanzeon Bodhisattva, which is enshrined as a secret Buddha in the inner sanctuary of the main hall. In the history, it was said that the memorial service was held for the spirits of the dead. I received a goshuin for my prayers.

Review:

You can watch it slowly.

Author: Y C
Review:
On the way from Yasaka Shrine to Kiyomizu Temple, I happened to pass by here and was attracted by the huge Guanyin statue, so I bought a ticket to enter.
The entire park of Lingshan Guanyin is located at the foot of Dongshan Mountain. It is mainly composed of the statue of Guanyin, the mirror pond, the wish-fulfilling jewel, the Buddha's foot stone, the flower tomb, the hall of Aizen Mingwang, the twelve zodiac deities, the gomo hall, the lotus hall, the monument to the unknown soldier of World War II, and the stillborn child site. It is composed of Tibetan Zun and Chaojing Hall.

Lingshan Avalokitesvara Statue: Built in 1955 by the founder of the Disan Group to commemorate the fallen soldiers and victims of World War II, with the image of "Avalokitesvara in white" as the image, the statue is solemn. The Guanyin statue is 24 meters high and weighs about 500 tons. It is a reinforced concrete structure. Below the Kannon statue is a shrine enshrining the main image of the eleven-faced Kannon.

Ruyi Orb: Also called the Wishing Orb, in front of Guanyin's right hand, it is a place where wishes can come true! It is said that touching the wishful jewel with the right hand, and at the same time recite the wish silently in the heart, while turning the wishful jewel three times clockwise, then the wish will come true! According to the introduction, Lingshan Guanyin is located in a place of geomantic omen, and it has been known to the public as an auspicious place since ancient times. In the Heian period, it was a holy place where the secret treasure of esoteric Buddhism, "Nengzuu Cintama", was buried.

Hall of King Aidanming: King Aidanming is the king of esoteric Buddhism, who lives in the samadhi of great love and greed. After Esoteric Buddhism spread to Japan, Dongmi (Japanese Esoteric Buddhism) derived the meaning of "love, good marriage, and happy family". Therefore, Lord Aizenmei became the god of love in Japan. Therefore, this place has also become a holy place to pray for a good relationship and a happy family.

Monument to the Unknown Soldier of World War II: Supported by the heroic spirits of the unknown soldiers from all over the world (not limited to Japan) who died for their country in World War II, it is said that four memorial services are held every day.
Zodiac deities guard: Located in the body of Guanyin Bodhisattva, there are deities that protect each zodiac. You can visit according to your zodiac sign.

Buddha's foot stone: The footprint is very huge, which is a symbol of Sakyamuni. It is carved side by side in the shape of Buddha's right and left footprints. The rock is five meters long and two meters six wide.

Stillborn child Jizang Zun: A special prayer place for the little lives who died young, praying that the souls of the water children who could not enjoy the heavenly life can rest in peace in a peaceful and peaceful environment. It is the beauty of Japan to have such a dedicated place to pray for children who have died.

Flower Tomb: Located in a small corner of the garden with verdant trees, there is a monument standing, quiet and serene, with a burst of red, quite Zen-like.

Tickets: 300 yen
Visiting time: 8:40-16:20 (stop selling tickets at 16:00)

Author: JJ
Review:
Despite being quite overlooked and not as popular as some of the other temples in the area, the temple is truly beautiful and well worth the visit.

When I visited the temple, it was snowing, which made the experience even more magical and unforgettable. The temple's grounds had an area covered in a thick layer of snow, which was a lot of fun.

The temple's main hall is a stunning sight, with intricate architecture and traditional decorations. The statue of the Guan Yin, the goddess of mercy, is particularly impressive
